title: Do quarterbacks have an advantage when throwing indoors compared to open stadiums?
text:
There are 10 indoor or domed stadiums in the NFL. One huge factor for playing indoor is that the wind or weather doesn’t affect the quarterbacks. With no outside elements to deal with, QBs can throw to deeper routes more consistently and maintain better overall accuracy.
So that got me thinking, does playing indoor increase quarterbacks pass completion? And when you do play outside, does wind really play a factor when playing outdoors since you switch directions?
First let’s look at some data to see completion rate for indoor, dome and outdoor stadiums. Without wind or any other outdoor factors like the cold, I would only assume that throwing indoor would be significantly better than throwing outdoor.


Code
library(nflfastR)
library(ggplot2)

pbp_2024 <- load_pbp(2024)

pbp_2024_pass <- pbp_2024[pbp_2024$play_type == "pass", ]

completion_rate <- aggregate(
  cbind(total_pass_attempts = play_type) ~ roof, 
  data = pbp_2024_pass, 
  FUN = length
)

completion_rate$total_completions <- sapply(
  completion_rate$roof, 
  function(r) sum(pbp_2024_pass$complete_pass[pbp_2024_pass$roof == r] == 1, na.rm = TRUE)
)

completion_rate$completion_rate <- (completion_rate$total_completions / completion_rate$total_pass_attempts) * 100

ggplot(completion_rate, aes(x = roof, y = completion_rate, fill = roof)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", show.legend = FALSE) +
  labs(
    title = "Wind doesn’t change completion rates across stadium types", 
    subtitle = "Whether indoors or outdoors, quarterbacks perform consistently",
    x = "Roof Type",
    y = "Completion Rate (%)",
    caption = "Source: nflfastR | Graphic: Christian Naujokaitis"
  ) +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = sprintf("%.1f%%", completion_rate)), 
    vjust = -0.5, size = 4
  ) +
 theme(
  panel.background = element_rect(fill = "grey90"), 
  plot.background = element_rect(fill = "grey90"),
  plot.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
  plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10, hjust = 0.5),
  plot.caption = element_text(size = 8, hjust = 1, face = "italic"),
  axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 10)
) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("dome" = "blue", "outdoors" = "#006400", "closed" = "#8B0000"))









Based on my initial question, I was wrong, there really isn’t a difference.
The great thing about NFLFastR is that it breaks down each play and even gives data about the weather. One stat that I pulled from was the wind per play. It’s super helpful because you can see exactly how much wind was present on every snap, which makes it easier to connect how weather might’ve impacted a QB’s performance. Instead of just guessing if wind played a role, you’ve got the numbers to back it up. It’s a solid way to add some context when looking at passing efficiency or accuracy on a game-by-game basis.
But how much does wind actually play a factor when throwing the ball? According to the New York Times, passes thrown in wind speeds of 15 miles per hour or more are likely to be affected. That means anything above that threshold can mess with a quarterback’s accuracy, timing, and distance.
So in the data below, I found out the completions vs the amount of passes when the wind is less than 15 mph and more than 15 mph. The goal originally was to see how completion rate was during windy days, but I noticed a bigger stat from the waffle chart.


Code
library(waffle)
library(ggplot2)
#| warning: false
#| message: false

wi <- c("Attempts" = 688, "Completions" = 403)
nw <- c("Attempts" = 11962 / 100, "Completions" = 7269 / 100)

waffle(
  wi, 
  rows = 25, 
  title = "Passing takes a hit on windy days",    
  xlab = "1 square = 1 pass",                     
  colors = c("black", "green")
) +
  labs(
    subtitle = "On days with wind over 15 mph, throwing rates drop noticeably compared to non-windy days",
    caption = "Source: nflfastR | Graphic: Christian Naujokaitis"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 8, face = "italic")
  )









Code
waffle(
  nw, 
  rows = 10, 
  title = "Clear skies = more throws",          
  xlab = "1 square = 100 passes",                 
  colors = c("black", "green")
) +
  labs(
    subtitle = "When wind is calm, quarterbacks throw passes at a much higher rate.",
    caption = "Source: nflfastR | Graphic: Christian Naujokaitis"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 8, face = "italic")
  )









One thing to pay attention to is how many passes are thrown on non-windy days versus windy ones. There are way more passes on calm days—each square represents 100 passes, and you can really see the difference. So yeah, it’s pretty clear that non-windy conditions are way more common.
Now, while wind doesn’t seem to mess with completion rates much, it does have a big impact on how far the ball gets thrown. At first, I thought wind would only be a problem if you were throwing against it, but I was way off. Turns out, when the wind picks up, it doesn’t matter if it’s at your back or in your face,the deep ball pretty much disappears.
In the chart below, I marked some of the deeper passes (anything over 80 yards). Once wind speeds hit around 10 mph or more, those deep throws start to drop off fast.


Code
library(nflfastR)
library(ggplot2)

pbp_2024 <- load_pbp(2024)

pbp_2024_clean <- pbp_2024[complete.cases(pbp_2024$wind, pbp_2024$passing_yards), ]

# Identify the row where passing yards exceed 80
pbp_2024_clean$color <- ifelse(pbp_2024_clean$passing_yards > 80, "red", "black")

ggplot(pbp_2024_clean, aes(x = wind, y = passing_yards)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = color), alpha = 0.6, show.legend = FALSE) +  # Remove the color key
  scale_color_manual(values = c("black", "red")) +  # Map the color
  labs(
    title = "Wind has a major impact on deep passing yards",  
    subtitle = "Strong winds affect deep passes, but short throws remain mostly unaffected.",
    x = "Wind Speed (mph)",
    y = "Passing Yards",
    caption = "Source: nflfastR | Graphic: Christian Naujokaitis"  
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = 8, face = "italic")
  )









At the end of the day, playing indoors doesn’t really boost a quarterback’s completion rate, but it does make a difference in how many yards they rack up. When there’s wind or bad weather, QBs can still complete passes by keeping it short—but throwing deep gets a lot trickier.

title: Was it the Cavs’ greatness or the Warriors’ collapse
text:
Some of the best things in the world came out in 2016: AirPods, Stranger Things, and most importantly, the 2016 NBA Finals.
The NBA Finals in 2016 will go down in the record books as one of the best playoffs in sports history. For context:The Golden State Warriors, coming off a record-breaking 73-9 regular season, were heavily favored, led by Stephen Curry. The Cleveland Cavaliers, with LeBron James, were aiming to deliver Cleveland’s first-ever NBA Championship. After the Warriors took a 2-0 series lead, the Cavs fought back, winning Game 3 and then Game 4 to tie things up at 2-2. The Warriors regained control in Game 5, putting Cleveland in a tough spot with a 3-1 lead. But LeBron and Kyrie Irving weren’t done. They made an incredible comeback, winning Games 6 and 7. Game 7 was a classic, with LeBron’s iconic chase-down block on Andre Iguodala and Kyrie hitting a clutch three-pointer late. The Cavs won 93-89, claiming their first NBA title and LeBron’s long-awaited championship. It remains one of the greatest comebacks in NBA history. Now, did the Cavs have one of the best underdog stories, or did the Warriors just choke under pressure?
Lets compare the playoff stats between the two most notable players.


Code
library(tidyverse)




Code
playerdata <- read.csv("data/playerdata.csv")

df <- playerdata[playerdata$Player %in% c("LeBron James", "Stephen Curry"), ]

lebron <- df[df$Player == "LeBron James", c("FG", "FGA", "X3P", "AST", "PTS")]
curry <- df[df$Player == "Stephen Curry", c("FG", "FGA", "X3P", "AST", "PTS")]

comp_data <- data.frame(
  Player = rep(c("LeBron", "Curry"), each = 5),
  Stat = rep(c("FG", "FGA", "3P", "AST", "PTS"), times = 2),
  Value = c(as.numeric(lebron), as.numeric(curry))
)

ggplot(comp_data, aes(x = Stat, y = Value, fill = Player)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = position_dodge(width = 0.8)) +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(Value, 2)), 
            position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), 
            vjust = -0.5,
            check_overlap = TRUE) + 
  labs(
    title = "More Threes ≠ More Overall Points",
    subtitle = "Despite Stephen Curry's edge in three-pointers, LeBron James led in total points",
    x = "Stats",
    y = "Amount",
    caption = "Data from basketball-reference.com | Graphic by Christian Naujokaitis"
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#1D428A", "#860038")) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(face = "italic")
  )









Next let’s compare everyone in the playoffs to show some of the most dominant players in the Playoffs. Some names to look at Kevin Durant, as he was in his prime along with James Harden and Paul George.


Code
library(gt)

playerdata$PPG <- playerdata$PTS / playerdata$G

playerdata_ordered <- playerdata[order(-playerdata$PPG), ]

top_scorers <- playerdata_ordered[1:10, c("Player", "G", "PTS", "PPG")]

top_scorers |> 
  gt() |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Curry and James not at the top of the scorers list",
    subtitle = "Despite going to the finals, they remain low on charts for points per game"
  ) |>
  cols_label(
    G = "Games Played",
    PTS = "Total Points",
    PPG = "Points Per Game"
  ) |>
  fmt_number(
    columns = PPG,
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#ADD8E6"),  
      cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Stephen Curry"
    )
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "yellow"),  
      cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold")
    ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "LeBron James"
    )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |>
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
  tab_style(
    style = cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(2)), 
    locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything())  # Fixed this line
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**Data from basketball-reference.com | Graphic by Christian Naujokaitis**")
  )

Something interesting to pull from this chart is how Curry played 6 less games than his teammate Klay Thompson. Why? In the first round against the Houston Rockets, he sprained his right ankle in Game 1 and missed the next two games. Then, in Game 4, he slipped on a wet spot just before halftime and suffered a Grade 1 MCL sprain in his right knee. That injury kept him out for two weeks, including the rest of that series and the start of the second round. He returned in Game 4 against the Portland Trail Blazers and famously scored 17 points in overtime, finishing with 40 total. While he was able to play the rest of the playoffs, many believe he wasn’t quite 100% by the time the Finals rolled around, even though he never used it as an excuse.
Now let’s look at a direct comparison between how players on the Cavs vs the Warriors matched up in points and turnover ratio. In the graph below, it is players on both teams with over 200 total points in the playoffs. At the top of both categories, LeBron and Curry. Following shortly behind is Kyrie Irving and Klay Thompson, the other key weapons for both teams.


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(ggrepel)

filtered_data <- playerdata[playerdata$Tm %in% c("GSW", "CLE") & playerdata$PTS >= 200, ]

ggplot(filtered_data, aes(x = PTS, y = TOV, label = Player)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = PTS, size = TOV), alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_text_repel(size = 3, max.overlaps = Inf) +  # Smart label placement
  labs(
    title = "Some players made a sneaky impact",
    subtitle = "How players on CLE and GSW matched up while scoring 200+ points in the playoffs",
    x = "Points",
    y = "Turnovers",
    caption = "Data from basketball-reference.com | Graphic by Christian Naujokaitis"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red") + 
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0, face = "italic", size = 8)
  )









So back to the question. Did the Warriors choke when it mattered the most, or did the Cavs make the best comeback of all time? I would say both, but unfortunately for the Warriors they ran into one of the best all around players of all time during their peak. I don’t think anyone was going to stop LeBron from giving Clevland their first ring.
